title: Prognostic Scores: IPSS – International Prognostic Scoring System – Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS)
summary: Comprehensive guide to IPSS, IPSS-R and IPSS-M prognostic scoring systems for myelodysplastic syndromes, including clinical applications and molecular integration.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: Topic 6: IPSS – International Prognostic Scoring System – Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS)
Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a clonal disorder of hematopoietic stem cells, characterized by:

items: Ineffective hematopoiesis leading to peripheral cytopenias
Bone marrow dysplasia
Genomic instability with diverse mutational profiles
Potential for progression to acute myeloid leukemia (AML)

content.text: Given the high heterogeneity in clinical behavior—from indolent cytopenias to rapidly progressive disease—risk stratification tools are critical for:

items: Estimating overall survival (OS) and AML transformation risk
Guiding treatment intensity
Determining transplant timing
Structuring clinical trial enrollment

content.text: Prognostic scoring systems have evolved over decades, transitioning from morphology-based models to molecularly integrated algorithms like IPSS-M.

rows: First international standard; 3 parameters (cytopenias, blasts, cytogenetics)
Refined cytogenetics (5-tier), continuous hematologic data, improved risk tiers
Integration of 31 gene mutations via NGS; advanced risk modeling

content.text: IPSS-M represents the next generation of personalized medicine in MDS care, enabling a biologically driven approach.
The original IPSS was based on clinical and pathologic parameters at diagnosis:

items: Bone marrow blasts: <5%, 5–10%, 11–20%, 21–30%
Cytogenetics (Good, Intermediate, Poor)
Number of cytopenias (Hgb <10 g/dL, ANC <1800/μL, Platelets <100k/μL)

content.text: Widely used for transplant decisions and early treatment referral in the pre-molecular era.
The IPSS-R used data from >7,000 patients to enhance prognostic accuracy.

items: More granular cytogenetic risk classification:
5 categories: Very Good, Good, Intermediate, Poor, Very Poor
Continuous scoring of:
Hemoglobin
Platelet count
ANC
Blast percentage
Expanded risk groups: Very Low to Very High

content.text: IPSS-R is the most widely used clinical tool in daily practice and trials.
The IPSS-M reflects the current era of molecular oncology, integrating 31 prognostic gene mutations derived from next-generation sequencing (NGS) data.

items: Includes all IPSS-R parameters
Adds mutation status for genes such as:
TP53, SF3B1, ASXL1, SRSF2, EZH2, RUNX1, ETV6, NRAS
Stratifies into 6 risk groups (Very Low to Very High)
Provides superior discrimination of OS and AML progression risk
Detects poor prognosis even in 'low-risk' cytogenetic profiles (e.g., TP53 mutations)
Improves identification of transplant candidates
Available via online calculator: mds-risk-model.com

rows: Sets prognosis and informs need for active treatment
IPSS-R High or IPSS-M High/Very High → early referral

content.text: In resource-limited settings, IPSS-R remains the practical standard due to limited access to NGS.

rows: IPSS-M not feasible in all clinical environments
IPSS systems use diagnosis-only data, not dynamic status
Doesn't factor in age, frailty, cardiac/renal disease
Lab values and marrow estimates may differ by institution
Validated only in adults; pediatric MDS requires separate tools

content.text: 9. Complementary Tools for Full Risk Assessment

rows: Tailors therapy intensity for elderly MDS

content.text: A multimodal approach using IPSS-M, comorbidity scores, and MRD is becoming standard in specialized centers.

rows: Supportive care, ESAs, lenalidomide (del(5q)), monitor progression
Prompt HMA therapy, transplant referral, clinical trial enrollment

items: ESAs (EPO, darbepoetin) – first-line for anemia in low-risk
Lenalidomide – especially effective in isolated del(5q) MDS
Luspatercept – approved for ring sideroblast-associated anemia
Azacitidine/Decitabine – HMA standard for high-risk patients
ATG + Cyclosporine – for hypoplastic or autoimmune-associated MDS

content.text: Only allogeneic HSCT offers a potential cure, but it's reserved for select, fit patients.
The International Prognostic Scoring System (IPSS) and its successors, IPSS-R and IPSS-M, form the cornerstone of risk-based management in MDS.

items: IPSS: Pioneering model, still referenced but outdated.
IPSS-R: Clinical standard, widely adopted and validated.
IPSS-M: Molecularly integrated, allows precision risk stratification, but requires NGS access.
Better discrimination of survival outcomes
More accurate AML transformation prediction
Improved ability to select patients for transplant or clinical trials

content.text: As genomic testing becomes routine and dynamic markers like MRD are integrated, future scoring systems will likely evolve into adaptive, AI-supported tools guiding real-time decision-making in MDS care.

items: Use IPSS-R as baseline risk assessment for all new MDS diagnoses
Consider IPSS-M testing for patients with discordant features or transplant candidates
Reassess risk status at progression or treatment failure
Combine with comorbidity assessment for treatment decisions
Document IPSS score in all MDS patient records for trial eligibility
